solution.text:
As per the theorem that says if x=\(\frac pq\) be a rational number where p and q are coprime, such that the prime factorization of q is of the form \(2^n\times 5^m\).
Then, x has a decimal expansion which is terminating.
So, we just need to check for the denominator(q) of the given fraction
if q is a factor of only prime number 2 or 5 then it will be terminating and will be entered in the computer
So we solve and get,\(\frac {_{{j+4}}_}{_{{16*k}}_}=\frac {_{{j+4}}_}{_{k}_\times 2^4}\)
similarly, \(\frac {_{{j+3}}_}{_{{25*k}}_}=\frac {_{{j+3}}_}{5^2\times _{k}_}\)
also \(\frac {_{{j+7}}_}{_{{20*k}}_}=\frac {_{{j*7}}_}{5\times 2^2 \times _{k}_}\)
But in other the ratios ,denominators contain prime factors other than 2 and 5

content.text:
School administration enters attendance record of the students of classes 1st to 8th in a computer.
The ratios of students present in the class to the total enrolled students are as follows: \(\frac {_{{j+1}}_}{_{{13*k}}_},\frac {_{{j+2}}_}{_{{14*k}}_},\frac {_{{j+3}}_}{_{{25*k}}_},\frac {_{{j+4}}_}{_{{16*k}}_},\frac {_{{j+5}}_}{_{{17*k}}_},\frac {_{{j+5}}_}{_{{18*k}}_},\frac {23}{41},\frac {_{{j+7}}_}{_{{20*k}}_}\)
It was later noticed that only those fractions that resulted into a terminating decimal number were entered and others were discarded
From the options given below, choose the ratios which were successfully entered into the computer
